definition:
*Cylindrical coordinates* are a system of coordinates for
$\mathbb{R}^3$. Two of the coordinates correspond to the polar
coordinates of $\mathbb{R}^2$, and the third coordinate corresponds with
the $z$ axis. Thus, the coordinates are given by

$$\left( \begin{array}{c}
x \\
y \\
z \end{array} \right)=\left( \begin{array}{c}
r \cos \theta \\
r \sin \theta \\
z \end{array} \right),$$

where $r$ is the distance from $(0,0,0)$ to $(x,y,0)$ and $\theta$ is
the azimuthal angle defined for $\theta \in [0,2\pi )$.

Just as with polar coordinates, one can convert from Cartesian
coordinates to cylindrical coordinates for any point not lying on the
$z$ axis via

$$\begin{aligned}
r(x,y) &=& \sqrt{x^2+ y^2}, \\
\theta(x,y) &=& \arctan (x,y),\end{aligned}$$

where $\arctan$ is defined .
